wildlife_gallery.name: African Lion
wildlife_gallery.description: The 'King of the Jungle,' known for its majestic mane and social pride structure.
wildlife_gallery.fact: A lion's roar can be heard from as far as 8 kilometers away.

wildlife_gallery.name: African Elephant
wildlife_gallery.description: The largest land animal on Earth, possessing high intelligence and complex social bonds.
wildlife_gallery.fact: Elephants communicate through low-frequency sounds called infrasound.

wildlife_gallery.name: African Buffalo
wildlife_gallery.description: Also known as the Cape Buffalo, it is one of the most successful grazers in Africa.
wildlife_gallery.fact: Buffaloes have a 'voting' behavior where they signal the direction they want to move.

wildlife_gallery.name: Leopard
wildlife_gallery.description: The most elusive of the big cats, famous for its climbing ability and spotted coat.
wildlife_gallery.fact: Leopards often drag their kills high into trees to protect them from scavengers.

wildlife_gallery.name: Black Rhinoceros
wildlife_gallery.description: A powerful herbivore characterized by its two horns and prehensile upper lip.
wildlife_gallery.fact: Rhinos have been around for over 50 million years.

wildlife_gallery.name: Elephant Shrew
wildlife_gallery.description: A tiny insectivore with a long, flexible snout resembling an elephant's trunk.
wildlife_gallery.fact: They are more closely related to elephants than to true shrews.

wildlife_gallery.name: Ant Lion
wildlife_gallery.description: A predatory insect whose larvae dig funnel-shaped pits in the sand to trap ants.
wildlife_gallery.fact: They spend most of their lives in the larval stage, waiting for prey.

wildlife_gallery.name: Rhinoceros Beetle
wildlife_gallery.description: Large beetles with horn-like structures used for fighting rivals during mating season.
wildlife_gallery.fact: They can lift objects 850 times their own body weight.

wildlife_gallery.name: Leopard Tortoise
wildlife_gallery.description: The fourth largest tortoise in the world, marked with yellow and black spots.
wildlife_gallery.fact: They can live for up to 100 years and are surprisingly fast swimmers.

wildlife_gallery.name: Red-billed Buffalo Weaver
wildlife_gallery.description: A social bird that builds large, messy communal nests in thorny trees.
wildlife_gallery.fact: They are often the first birds to sound an alarm when a predator is nearby.
